text: the charge is a natural property of protons and electrons. It does not appear to come from anywhere, it just exists. Since the two types of charge tend to cancel each other out, picking one to call negative and the other to call positive is a reasonable convention.

text: Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway.
question: How plants respond to nature?

text: Metabolism definitely varies between people. Metabolism can be defined as the sum of all of the chemical reactions occurring inside of a living organism. Metabolism varies depending on the conditions present inside of the organism. The human body can speed up and slow down the rates of different chemical processes simultaneously in an attempt to maintain homeostasis. So weight can affect metabolism, but it certainly isn't the only factor that does so. A person's activity level, hormone levels, age, energy intake, and overall health can also impact metabolism.
question: Does metabolism vary widely between people?

text: presently all cells come from other cells - this means that any existing cell got the ribosomes it begins with from a progenitor cell, so any protein (including new ribosomal proteins) will initially be made by a ribosome that came from a progenitor cell. Enzymes can also be made from RNA and RNA is actually still used to catalyze some critical cellular processes such as translation. These observations led to the hypothesis that there was an "RNA world" in which RNA served to both store information (like DNA does now) and to catalyze reactions (as is now usually done by proteins).
question: Does Ribosome exists first or Protein does?

text: Interestingly enough, so-called idiot savants, do not have a greater capacity for computation, music, or art. Instead, the parts of their brains responsible for such tasks dominate the rest of their brain because the parts that would normally compete for attention are either damaged or unable to communicate effectively with the rest of the brain. Researchers have used something called TMS (trans-cranial magnetic stimulation) to induce small currents in parts of the brain, either shutting down or activating specific regions of the brain temporarily. Their research has shown that it is possible to temporarily induce a savant-like state in normally functioning brains. And, of course, some forms of brain damage can induce temporary or permanent savant-like states as well.
question: Does human beings have the capacity to use all areas of cerebral cortex or only few designated areas?

text: We cannot obtain usable nitrogen through breathing. Nitrogen has to be fixed into a usable form first before it is consumed by heterotrophs. Plants can take this form in, and help convert nitrogen into amino acids/proteins and nucleic acids.
question: Do we also breathe in the nitrogen in the atmosphere and do we take in this nitrogen?

text: Osmosis and dissolving are different processes! Dissolving is what happens when molecules or ions in a crystal (or other solid) disperse within a solution. For example, if I put salt or sugar into a cup of water it dissolves - note that there is no semi-permeable membrane involved. In contrast, osmosis is the tendency for water (or another solvent) to move across a semi-permeable membrane to decrease differences in solute concentration.
question: Salt was dissolved in the digestive system so why would osmosis need to dissolve it again when diffusing the salt?

question: How come Li has more reduction potential than Na or K?

It has no known substructure and is believed to be a point particle Electrons participate in gravitational, electromagnetic and weak interactions. Like its rest mass and elementary charge, the intrinsic angular momentum (or spin) of an electron has a constant value. In the collision of an electron and a positron, the electron's antiparticle, both are annihilated. An electron-positron pair can be produced from gamma ray photons with sufficient energy.
question: What gives an electron a negative charge and what gives a proton a positive charge?

text: sexual reproduction evolved via natural selection. Some very primitive form of sexual reproduction (probably just sharing DNA randomly between single cells) led to greater variation in one population vs another. On a population scale, sexual reproduction clearly offers a selective advantage. The new-found variation means that the population as a whole can thrive in a wider variety of conditions because individuals are less similar to each other and the population as a whole can therefore survive in a wider variety of conditions. For example, let's say there is a population of cells that normally can survive in only dry, hot conditions. Let's say that through random mutation (which is pretty rare), one member of that population develops an allele of a gene that allows it to survive in humid conditions, and another member develops an allele of a different gene that allows it to survive in cold conditions. If the population can only reproduce asexually (i.e. by budding off clones), you would never find an individual that could survive both humidity AND cold. So, if the desert where this population of cells lives cooled AND humidified (maybe there's an ice age), none of the individuals of that asexually reproducing population would survive. BUT, if they did reproduce sexually, there could be an individual with BOTH new alleles who could survive both cold AND humidity. So in this scenario, sexual reproduction is a selective advantage over asexual reproduction. However, the original version of sexual reproduction was probably very, very simple compared to how it works in humans - remember, our version of sexual reproduction has had a ton of time to evolve its complexities.
question: Why/how was sexual reproduction introduced?
